Well the bare minimum was JUnit 4 I suppose because I wanted to use
the @Ru=
nWith annotation - was there an easy way to write custom
runners prior to J=
Unit 4?

As for 4.4 versus earlier versions, it has to do with classes
avai=
lable in the release. For example, JUnit4Runner is an internal
class (I kno=
w I should not depend on internal classes but it made the
work so easy).

S=
o the Eclipse version, which ships with JUnit 4.3 could not depend on
the s=
ame base class as the JUnit 4.4-based version, which ships with
IntelliJ.

=
So, really, the only limitation is my use of an internal class.

Also, I *t=
hink* the version of the jar that ships with Eclipse is
missing the classes=
 in the internal package.
